docs.snippet: ASUNCION, Paraguay Latin America's most durable dictatorship has lasted so long that most Paraguayans were not even born when Gen. Alfredo Stroessner took power.
docs.lead_paragraph: ASUNCION, Paraguay Latin America's most durable dictatorship has lasted so long that most Paraguayans were not even born when Gen. Alfredo Stroessner took power.
docs.abstract: Article on Paraguayan Gen Alfredo Stroessner's durable dictatorship notes Paraguay has escaped turmoil of pol instability, mil coups and guerrilla movements that has affected all her neighbors in last decade; discusses activities in daily life of Stroessner; notes Paraguay remains one of most backward nations in Latin Amer, with illiteracy estimated to be around 50% and 1/3 of population speaking only Guarani Indian lanugage; says per capita income is about $300 annually and does not take into account unequal distribution of meager wealth; repts country has only 1,100 drs for population of about 2.5-million, infant mortality rate is among highest in hemisphere and vast majority of Paraguayans suffer from intestinal viruses; notes 60% of population live in rural interior or villages devoid of machines; holds country is in constant state of siege, under which all const guarantees are suspended; describes torture and detention of Lusi Alfonso Resch, Carmen Lara Castro, Congresswoman and pres of Human Rights Comm, Sen Carlos Levi Rufinelli, and excommunication of RC Ch officials; cites strained relations between Ch and Govt; map; illus of Pres Stroessner (L)

headline.main: Stroessner's 'Reign of Peace' in Paraguay Has a Price

byline.original: By JONATHAN KANDELL Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Twenty Latin American and Caribbean countries today voted condemnation of the new United States trade act as "discriminatory and coercive" in a resolution by the governing body of the Organization of American States.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 Twenty Latin American and Caribbean countries today voted condemnation of the new United States trade act as "discriminatory and coercive" in a resolution by the governing body of the Organization of American States.
docs.abstract: OAS Permanent Council votes condemnation of new US trade act as 'discriminatory and coercive' because act bars Venezuela and Ecuador, both OPEC members, from new tariff preferences, Jan 23 meeting of Permanent Council; US abstains; several Latin Amer delegates say trade-law issue is serious enough to warrant interrupting new hemisphere dialogue inaugurated in '74 between Latin Amer and US by Sec Kissinger; resolution expresses orgn's deep concern over deterioration of inter-Amer solidarity caused by provisions of US foreign trade act of '74, which reprs of Latin Amer countries say distort gen system of preferences, establish discriminatory and coercive measures in detriment to countries of Latin Amer, and run counter to fundamental provisions of charter of OAS; Venezuelan delegate Jose Maria Machin says 'coercive' aspects of law are of such magnitude that it would disturb atmosphere of scheduled meeting of hemisphere foreign mins in Buenos Aires in Mar; Argentine diplomats disclose that their Foreign Ministry began asking other hemisphere govts whether they consider Mar meeting appropriate in view of climate created by trade act; vote is setback for US; US delegate John W Ford says that over 90% of Venezuela's and Ecuador's exports to US are already free of tariffs; says US abstention was necessary because resolution fails to present balanced picture of trade act in its full dimensions; OAS resolution calls for debate on trade law at Gen Assembly meeting in Apr following study by group's secretariat and inter-Amer Econ and Soc Council (M)

headline.main: 20 Latin Countries Condemn U.S. Trade Act

byline.original: By DABID BINDER Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: MEXICO CITY Growing pessimism about Mexico's economic future has been abruptly transformed into optimism by important new oil discoveries in the southeast of the country.
docs.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY Growing pessimism about Mexico's economic future has been abruptly transformed into optimism by important new oil discoveries in the southeast of the country.
docs.abstract: Article on importance of recent oil discoveries in SE Mex notes Govt efforts to keep domestic oil prices artificially low had left state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, without sufficient funds to spur exploration; notes enterprise began $2.9-billion investment program aimed at vastly expanding output and refining capacity after sudden rise in price of oil imports forced Govt to change policy; discusses extent of potential output and reserves (Intl Econ Survey) (M)

headline.main: Mexico Becomes Oil Exporter; Mexico Becomes Oil Exporter

docs.snippet: Pension plans are growing in a patchwork pattern around the world to cope with what was once, in a simpler time, mostly a family problem of caring for those who no longer could work.
docs.lead_paragraph: Pension plans are growing in a patchwork pattern around the world to cope with what was once, in a simpler time, mostly a family problem of caring for those who no longer could work.
docs.abstract: NY Times survey compares pension plans in Italy, France, W Ger, US, Canada, GB, People's Repub of China, USSR, Japan and Argentina; notes absence of plans in Hong Kong and most of Latin Amer; sees many pensioners returning to traditional way of living with families after retirement because of econ difficulties; illus (L)

headline.main: With Pensions Shaky, Retirees Look to Families

docs.snippet: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago The bizarre currents that carry petroleum about the Hemisphere quickened last month after an infusion from this small nation's new oil fields.
docs.lead_paragraph: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad and Tobago The bizarre currents that carry petroleum about the Hemisphere quickened last month after an infusion from this small nation's new oil fields.
docs.abstract: Survey on Latin Amer oil exporters notes emergence of Trinidad and Tobago among leading exporters; discusses refining operations in Trinidad, Aruba and Curacao; discusses output and export policies; oil refinery illus (Intl Econ Survey) (M)

headline.main: Trinidad Moves Up the Oil Ladder

docs.snippet: BOGOTA, Colombia Most commodities produced or traded in Latin America normally move on two levels, either along commercial channels or through the hands of smugglers.
docs.lead_paragraph: BOGOTA, Colombia Most commodities produced or traded in Latin America normally move on two levels, either along commercial channels or through the hands of smugglers.
docs.abstract: survey examines record smuggling activity in '74 in South America; smuggling seen as institutionalized to point where bankers finance operations and mfrs depend on contraband to keep indus moving; most govts appear to tolerate illegal activity, which helps ease shortages and keeps prices from rising further; drawing (Internatl Econ Survey) (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: AMERICAN NATIONS AND WESTERN HEMISPHERE POSSESSIONS

docs.snippet: Dr. Gallup tells us the 10 most admired people in America are nine politicians and Billy Graham. I doubt it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Gallup tells us the 10 most admired people in America are nine politicians and Billy Graham. I doubt it.
docs.abstract: R Baker, commenting on Gallup Polls, notes how figures most mentioned in news are named by public as most admired and turn up on Poll; drawing

docs.snippet: Juan Masnik, captain of Uruguay's World Cup team, has signed with the New York Cosmos, the North American Soccer League team announced yesterday.
docs.lead_paragraph: Juan Masnik, captain of Uruguay's World Cup team, has signed with the New York Cosmos, the North American Soccer League team announced yesterday.

headline.main: Masnik of Uruguay Signed by Cosmos

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 26 (UPI) Jose A. Mora, former Foreign Minister of Uruguay and Secretary General of the Organization of American States, died here today. He was 77 years old.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 26 (UPI) Jose A. Mora, former Foreign Minister of Uruguay and Secretary General of the Organization of American States, died here today. He was 77 years old.

headline.main: JOSE A. MORA, 77, DIPLOMAT, IS DEAD; Uruguayan Headed O.A.S. Envoy in Washington
